questions.text: A 3-year-old female child is diagnosed with cystic fibrosis after presenting with chronic cough, skin rashes, diarrhea, and foul-smelling stools. Considering her symptoms and the nature of her diagnosis, which vitamin is she most likely deficient in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinol

 

Option A:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis leads to pancreatic damage and decreased secretion of HCO3 − and pancreatic digestive enzymes → fat and protein are absorbed poorly.
  • Retinol is a fat-soluble vitamin which is absorbed along with lipid micelles. The other vitamins listed are water-soluble, their absorption is not significantly affected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Biotin: Biotin deficiency includes dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Injection of biotin 100–300 mg will cure these symptoms.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Its deficiency results in reduced DNA synthesis, Macrocytic Anemia, Hyperhomocysteinemia, Birth Defects and cancer.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Its deficiency manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis, Circumcorneal vascularization and Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis can lead to pancreatic insufficiency and problems with fat malabsorption, including the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Retinol, or Vitamin A, is a fat-soluble vitamin that is commonly deficient in patients with cystic fibrosis due to its malabsorption. Deficiency can contribute to the skin manifestations and may affect growth and immune function.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: 382-385,464-469.

questions.text: A patient presents with an abnormal ocular finding as shown in the image. Considering nutritional deficiencies, which vitamin is most likely deficient in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Option A:

 

The given condition is called “BITOT’s SPOT”.

 

EYE MANIFESTATIONS OF VITAMIN A DEFICIENCY:

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia - The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Xerophthalmia - conjunctival and corneal dryness
  • Bitot’s Spots - greyish-white triangular plaques adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • All the above-mentioned ocular changes are completely reversible with vitamin A supplementation.
  • Keratomalacia-softening of the cornea → Bacterial infection → corneal ulceration, perforation → total blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency → simultaneous folate deficiency due to the folate trap. C/F- all the manifestations of folate deficiency – reduced DNA synthesis, macrocytic anemia, hyperhomocysteinemia, Birth Defects and Cancer.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2: Manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth), Circumcorneal vascularization ,Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Includes Scurvy, Delayed Wound healing, Hemorrhagic tendency, and Weak bones. No eye manifestations are seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

Bitot's spots is a clinical sign of Vitamin A (Retinol) deficiency and understand the importance of this vitamin for ocular health. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to xerophthalmia and blindness if not treated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 558-559, Lippincott 7/e : P 375-377

questions.text: A young girl presents with deteriorating night vision. Upon examination, the exterior aspect of her forearm shows a distinctive skin finding. Given her visual symptoms and the skin presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Option A:

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a condition often associated with vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by follicular hyperkeratosis, presenting as dry, rough bumps on the skin, especially on the extensor surfaces like the forearms. The concurrent symptom of night blindness further supports the diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris: This common skin condition causes small, hard bumps that may make the skin feel like sandpaper, but it is not typically associated with night vision problems.

 

Option C. Darier's disease: A rare genetic disorder that causes skin changes, but these changes are not specifically linked to night vision deterioration.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema: While this can cause itching and dryness of the skin around hair follicles, it doesn't typically result in the systemic symptoms seen with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentations are due to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia: Visual acuity is diminished in dim light and the patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:
  • Follicular hyperkeratosis or phrynoderma due to hyperkeratinization of the epithelium lining the follicles →skin becomes rough.
  • Keratinizing metaplasia of the epithelium of the respiratory, gastro- intestinal and genitourinary tracts →epithelium is atrophied.
  • Keratinization of urinary tract epithelium →urinary calculi.
  • The alterations in skin may cause increased incidence of generalized infections.  

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 465 -468.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman presents with dry, ulcerated skin over her elbows and small, gray plaques on the conjunctiva of both eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinol Deficiency  

 

Option B:

 

The patient has vitamin A (retinol) deficiency, which occurs in people with nutritional deficiency or increased requirements.e.g., pregnant women and chronic diseases. 

 

EYE MANIFESTATIONS OF VITAMIN A DEFICIENCY:

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia - The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Xerophthalmia - conjunctival and corneal dryness
  • Bitot's Spots - greyish-white triangular plaques adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • All the above-mentioned ocular changes are completely reversible with vitamin A supplementation.
  • Keratomalacia -softening of the cornea → Bacterial infection → corneal ulceration, perforation → total blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vitamin C deficiency: Includes Scurvy, Delayed Wound healing, Haemorrhagic tendency, and Weak bones. No eye manifestations are seen.

 

Option C: Excessive Vitamin D3 intake: Include weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, weight loss and calcinosis.

 

Option D: Thiamine deficiency: Results in beriberi, Polyneuritis, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome -encephalopathy (ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia) and psychosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry, ulcerated skin and conjunctival plaques is indicative of Retinol (Vitamin A) deficiency, which can lead to xerosis (dry skin), hyperkeratosis, and Bitot's spots on the conjunctiva.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 546-551 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 465 -468

choices.text: Opsin and all trans retinal
Opsin and all trans retinol

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the composition of rhodopsin found in the rod cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Opsin and 11-cis retinal

 

Option A:

 

  • Rhodopsin is a membrane protein found in the photoreceptor cells of the retina, made up of opsin plus 11-cis-retinal and it is important in the visual cycle.
  • It plays important role in vision.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Opsin and 11-cis retinol: Retinol is the alcohol form of vitamin A and does not directly bind to opsin to form rhodopsin; it needs to be oxidized to retinal.

 

Option C. Opsin and all-trans retinal: While all-trans retinal is produced from 11-cis retinal after light absorption, it is not the form that combines with opsin to make rhodopsin.

 

Option D. Opsin and all-trans retinol: All-trans retinol is also not the correct component of rhodopsin; it is neither the chromophore nor does it directly bind to opsin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhodopsin is a light-sensitive receptor protein involved in visual phototransduction. It consists of opsin, an apoprotein, bound to 11-cis retinal, a chromophore. Upon photon absorption, 11-cis retinal changes to all-trans retinal, leading to a conformational change in rhodopsin that ultimately results in vision.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 547 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 465

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with complaints of dry, scaly skin over her knees and elbows, as well as evidence of retarded growth and skeletal deformities. Examination also reveals corneal ulceration. Based on these findings, which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for the skin manifestations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Option B:

 

SKIN & MUCOUS MEMBRANE LESIONS:

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis or phrynoderma results from hyperkeratinization of the epithelium lining the follicles.
  • The skin becomes rough.
  • Keratinizing metaplasia of the epithelium of the respiratory, gastro-intestinal and Genito–urinary tracts (urinary calculi).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vitamin C: Includes Scurvy- Gum becomes painful, swollen, spongy and loosening of teeth, Delayed Wound healing,  Infantile Scurvy (Barlow’s Disease), Haemorrhagic tendency-petechiae and ecchymoses or hematoma and Weak bones.

 

Option C: Vitamin D: C/F – restricted to bones → RICKETS & OSTEOMALACIA

 

Option D: Vitamin K: In children and adults, Vitamin K deficiency may be manifested as bruising tendency, ecchymotic patches, mucous membrane haemorrhage, post-traumatic bleeding, and internal bleeding. NO SKIN MANIFESTATIONS.

 

Educational objective:

 

The skin manifestations, alongside growth retardation, skeletal deformities, and eye changes such as corneal ulceration, are highly indicative of Vitamin A (Retinol) deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of epithelial tissues, vision, and normal growth and development.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 551, Vasudevan7/e: p 468.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who has recently lost a significant amount of weight due to a strict, fat-free diet comes to the clinic with complaints of severe hair loss. Given her dietary history and weight loss, which fat-soluble vitamin deficiency is most likely contributing to her alopecia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency can lead to alopecia (hair loss), as it is essential for maintaining epithelial tissue integrity, including skin and hair follicles.
  • A fat-free diet impairs absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), making Vitamin A deficiency a likely cause.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Biotin: Biotin (Vitamin B7) is water-soluble and deficiency can cause hair loss, but it's not the most likely issue in a fat-free diet, which affects fat-soluble vitamins.
  • Option B. Zinc: Zinc is a trace element, not a vitamin, though its deficiency can cause alopecia. However, it's not directly linked to fat malabsorption due to dietary fat restriction.
  • Option C. Vitamin H: Vitamin H is another name for biotin, so same reasoning as option A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) require dietary fat for absorption. A strict fat-free diet can lead to deficiencies, especially in Vitamin A, which plays a vital role in epithelial health, vision, and hair follicle maintenance. Deficiency of Vitamin A may manifest as alopecia, dry skin, and night blindness.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 551.

choices.text: Vitamin A promotes maintenance of epithelial tissue.
Vitamin A is necessary for hearing but not for vision.
Vitamin A is synthesized in skin.
All vitamin A derivatives are safe to use during pregnancy.

questions.text: In a nutrition counselling session focused on dietary vitamins, a nutritionist explains the functions and importance of vitamin A to a group of expectant mothers. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the role and characteristics of vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A promotes maintenance of epithelial tissue.

 

Option A:

 

Vitamin A is essential for the normal differentiation of epithelial tissue as well as normal reproduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vitamin A is necessary for hearing but not for vision:

 

  • Vitamin A is necessary for vision, not hearing.
  • The visual pigment rhodopsin (opsin + 11-cis-retinal) undergo photo bleaching →causing an impulse that is transmitted by the optic nerve to the brain.
  • Isomerized from trans- retinal, 11-cis-retinal combines with opsin to reform rhodopsin, making it ready for another photochemical cycle.

 

Option C. Vitamin A is synthesized in skin: It is not synthesized in the skin.

 

Vitamin D (derivatives of calciferol) can be synthesized in the skin under the influence of sunlight from 7-dehydrocholesterol, an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. All vitamin A derivatives are safe to use during pregnancy: A form of vitamin A is 13-cis-retinoic acid (Accutane), causes birth defects of the face and brain if taken during the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of epithelial tissues and vision. It is important to recognize the dietary sources of vitamin A and its significance in prenatal care, while also being aware of the teratogenic potential of certain vitamin A derivatives during pregnancy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 464.

choices.text: Rhodopsin is made up of the protein opsin + all trans retinal.
Unstable intermediates are Rhodopsin → Lumirhodopsin → Metarhodopsin-I → Opsin + all-trans retinal
Visual pigments are G-protein-coupled receptors
Inhibitory protein transducin stops the cycle

questions.text: A Professor is explaining Wald's visual cycle to a group of medical students and asks which of the following statements about the cycle is true:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Visual pigments are G-protein-coupled receptors

 

Option C:

 

  • Rhodopsin is a membrane protein made up of the protein opsin and 11-cis-retinal found in the photoreceptor cells of the retina plays an important role in vision.
  • When light falls on the retina, the 11-cis-retinal isomerizes to all-trans-retinal then form unstable intermediates such as Rhodopsin → Bathorhodopsin → Lumirhodopsin → Metarhodopsin-I → Metarhodopsin-II → Opsin + all-transretinal.
  • Visual pigments are G-protein-coupled receptors and 11-cis retinal locks the receptor protein (opsin) in its inactive form.
  • The isomerization and photo-excitation leads to activation of G-protein and generation of cyclic-GMP, which acts as the gate for cation specific channels.
  • Transducin is the G-protein present in retina and the nerve impulse generated in the retina is transmitted to visual centres in the brain and the signal is terminated by inhibitory protein beta-arrestin which can bind and inactivate rhodopsin.
  • Regeneration of 11-cis-retinal is shown in the image.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhodopsin is made up of the protein opsin and 11-cis-retinal.

 

Option B. The unstable intermediates produced are Rhodopsin → Bath rhodopsin → Lumirhodopsin → Met Rhodopsin-I → Metarhodopsin-II → Opsin + all-trans retinal.

 

Option D. Inhibitory protein beta-arrestin stops the cycle.

 

Educational objective:

 

Visual pigments, such as rhodopsin, are indeed G-protein-coupled receptors. Rhodopsin interacts with the G-protein transducin to initiate a signaling cascade that eventually leads to the excitation of nerve signals in response to light.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 465 -468.

choices.text: Excess intake of carotenoids
Skin and sclera becomes yellow
Beta-carotene is a pro-vitamin present in plant
Carrot contains good quantity of beta carotene

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic with concerns about her skin appearing yellow. She mentions that she has recently started a new health regimen that includes a significant increase in juicing and eating vegetables. She is particularly fond of carrots and sweet potatoes. Despite the yellowing of her skin, her eyes remain white. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin and sclera becomes yellow

 

Option B:

 

  • Hypervitaminosis A or Toxicity is due to excessive intake of vitamin A since it is stored.
  • Seen in children where parents are overzealous in supplementing the vitamins.
  • Symptoms of toxicity: anorexia, irritability, headache, peeling of skin, drowsiness, vomiting, bony exostosis and enlargement of liver.
  • Higher concentration of retinol increases lysosomal enzymes and finally cellular death.
  • Hypercarotenemia is due to persistent excessive consumption of foods rich in carotenoids and the skin becomes yellow, but there is no staining of sclera as in jaundice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Excess intake of carotenoids: This is true; hypercarotenemia is caused by an increased intake of carotenoids, which can happen with consuming large amounts of foods high in beta-carotene.

 

Option C. Beta-carotene is a pro-vitamin present in plants: This statement is correct; beta-carotene is a precursor to vitamin A and is abundant in many plant foods, including carrots and sweet potatoes.

 

Option D. Carrot contains a good quantity of beta-carotene: This is also true; carrots are well-known for their high beta-carotene content, which can contribute to hypercarotenemia with excessive consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypercarotenaemia, the skin can become yellow due to the deposition of carotenoids, but the sclera remains unaffected and does not turn yellow. This is key in differentiating hypercarotenemia from jaundice, where bilirubin deposition leads to yellowing of both the skin and sclera.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl reports difficulty seeing after 6 pm, alongside a history of frequent upper respiratory infections. Physical examination reveals follicular hyperkeratosis on the back of her arms and white patches on the outer sclera of both eyes. Based on these symptoms, which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible for her clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Option A:

 

  • The clinical presentations are due to Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia: Visual acuity is diminished in dim light and the patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:
    • Follicular hyperkeratosis or phrynoderma due to hyperkeratinization of the epithelium lining the follicles → skin becomes rough.
    • Keratinizing metaplasia of the epithelium of the respiratory, gastro- intestinal and genitourinary tracts → epithelium is atrophied.
    • Keratinization of urinary tract epithelium → urinary calculi.
    • The alterations in skin may cause increased incidence of generalized infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets in children resulting in insufficient mineralization of bone → bone deformities.

 

Option C. Vitamin E deficiency causes neurological problems such as spinocerebellar ataxia, retinopathy, peripheral neuropathy, myopathies and also anemia due to oxidative damage to red blood cells.

 

Option D. Vitamin K deficiency results in bruising tendency, ecchymotic patches, mucous membrane hemorrhage, post-traumatic bleeding and internal bleeding.

 

Educational objective:

 

The clinical manifestations of vitamin A deficiency, which include night blindness, increased susceptibility to infections, follicular hyperkeratosis, and Bitot's spots. Understanding these signs is crucial for diagnosing and addressing vitamin A deficiency, highlighting the importance of a diet sufficient in vitamin A to support vision, skin health, and immune function.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 467.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with headache, anorexia, pruritus, and poor weight gain. Concerned about his night vision issues, his mother had administered a health syrup recommended by a local non-professional for 5 months. An X-ray reveals hyperostosis in the mid-shafts of long bones. Based on these clinical findings, what is the most likely cause of the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A toxicity

 

Option C:

 

  • Hypervitaminosis A or Toxicity is due to excessive intake of vitamin A as it is a stored vitamin.
  • It is seen in children where parents have been overzealous in supplementing the vitamins.
  • Eskimos refrain themselves from eating the liver of polar bear due to its high vitamin A content.
  • Symptoms of toxicity: anorexia, irritability, headache, peeling of skin, drowsiness and vomiting due to increased intracranial tension. Swelling over long bones (bony exostosis) may occur with painful bones and also enlargement of the liver is seen in children.
  • Higher concentration of retinol increases lysosomal enzymes causing cellular death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypervitaminosis D Intake of doses above 10,000 units /day for long periods. Symptoms: weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension and weight loss. Hypercalcemia leads to calcification of soft tissues (metastatic calcification/calcinosis) in vascular and renal tissues.

 

Option B. Rickets is due to insufficient mineralization of bones seen in children →Bones become soft, pliable and bone growth is markedly affected. Classical bone deformities include weight bearing bones are bent, Bowlegs, Knock knee, Rickety rosary and Bossing of frontal bones, pigeon chest and Harrison’s sulcus etc.

 

Option D. Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake. C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema due to decreased serum albumin levels. Lab findings are not seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

Excessive consumption of vitamin A can lead to toxicity, presenting with systemic symptoms like headache, anorexia, pruritus, poor weight gain, and specific skeletal changes such as hyperostosis. This underscores the importance of balanced nutrient intake and the risks associated with unsupervised supplementation, particularly in children.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.

choices.text: Seen in population eating polar bears
Acute toxicity would result in Pseudotumor cerebri
Peroxisomes are damaged in toxicity

questions.text: During a discussion on the toxic effects of vitamins in excess, a clinical nutritionist presents a case study involving hypervitaminosis A. The participants are asked to evaluate various statements related to the condition and identify which one is incorrect. Which of the following statements about hypervitaminosis A is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes are damaged in toxicity

 

Option C:

 

Peroxisomes being damaged is not a recognized consequence of hypervitaminosis A. Hypervitaminosis A can lead to a range of toxic effects due to the accumulation of excess vitamin A in the body, but direct damage to peroxisomes is not among these effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Seen in populations eating polar bears: This is true, as liver from polar bears contains extremely high levels of vitamin A and consuming it can lead to acute vitamin A toxicity.

 

Option B. Acute toxicity can result in pseudotumor cerebri: Acute hypervitaminosis A can indeed lead to increased intracranial pressure, mimicking symptoms of a brain tumor, which is referred to as pseudotumor cerebri.

 

Option D. More prone to fractures: Chronic intake of excessive vitamin A has been linked to an increased risk of fractures due to its effect on bone remodeling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypervitaminosis A

 

  • Common in arctic explorers who depend on polar bear liver. (OPTION A)
  • Organelle damaged in hypervitaminosis:  Lysosomes (OPTION C)
  • Acute toxicity: Pseudotumor cerebri (headache, dizziness, vomiting, stupor, and blurred vision, symptoms that may be confused with a brain tumor) and exfoliative dermatitis, hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia are noted. (OPTION b)
  • Chronic toxicity: Intake of > 50,000 IU/day for > 3 months → causes weight loss, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, bony exostosis, bone and joint pain, decreased cognition, hepatomegaly progresses to cirrhosis.
  • Retinoic acid stimulates osteoclast production and activity → increased bone resorption and high risk of fractures, especially hip fractures. (OPTION D)
  • In pregnancy, retinoids cause teratogenic effects.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.

choices.text: Human and cow (not goat) milk, uncooked fruits, and vegetables
Milk, eggs, meats, and fruits
Egg yolks, fish oils, and leafy vegetables

questions.text: In a nutritional counselling session for eye health, a dietitian addresses concerns from individuals experiencing dry eyes and difficulty seeing in low-light conditions. Which group of foods should the dietitian recommend helping alleviate these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Egg yolks, fish oils, and leafy vegetables

 

Option D:

 

  • Vitamin A is a fat-soluble that can be deficient in combination with thiamine and riboflavin deficiencies in dry climates with food shortages, with other fat-soluble vitamins (D, E, K) in disorders associated with intestinal malabsorption, and in hypothyroidism where there is defective conversion of carotene to vitamin A.
  • Carotenes and carotenoids in plants (yellow corn, carrots, sweet potatoes, leafy vegetables, and green peas → converted → retinaldehyde → retinol (found in egg yolks, fish oils, butter, liver, and kidney).
  • The first symptoms of vitamin A deficiency are dryness of the eyes (xerophthalmia) with decreased vision in dim light (night blindness), followed by photophobia, corneal irritation, ulceration, and destruction of the eye. Dry skin and rashes also occur.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Human and cow (not goat) milk, uncooked fruits, and vegetables are sources of Tetrahydrofolate.

 

Option B. Milk, eggs, meats, and fruits are sources of Riboflavin.

 

Option C. Vegetables, cereals, and fruits are sources of Pyridoxine.

 

The given deficiency manifestations are not seen in deficiency of THFA, Riboflavin and Pyridoxine.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry eyes and decreased vision in dim light can be symptoms of vitamin A deficiency. Foods rich in vitamin A or its precursors, such as beta-carotene, include egg yolks, fish oils, and leafy green vegetables. These foods can help improve eye health and vision in low-light conditions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p464-469

questions.text: A patient presents with a specific eye finding, indicative of a nutritional deficiency. Based on the visual symptom related to the eye, which vitamin deficiency is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Option B:

 

  • The given eye manifestation is Keratomalacia due to vitamin A deficiency.
  • When the xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia, which causes softening of the cornea.
  • Then there occurs degeneration of corneal epithelium which might get vascularized → develop corneal opacities later.
  • Bacterial infection on it leads to corneal ulceration, perforation of cornea and total blindness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Deficiency primarily leads to scurvy, which can cause gum disease and skin issues, but not typically the eye conditions associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B: Some B vitamins are important for eye health, particularly vitamin B2 (riboflavin), but the specific changes in the conjunctiva and cornea are more characteristic of vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin E: While vitamin E is an antioxidant important for general health, its deficiency does not usually result in eye changes as specific as those caused by vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is known to cause various eye issues, including xerophthalmia, which can lead to changes in the conjunctiva and cornea. The severe end of the spectrum of vitamin A deficiency involves damage to the cornea, a condition called keratomalacia, which can cause blindness.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 465 -468.

questions.text: Which of the following is highlighted as a primary source of beta-carotene?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yellow and red fruits

 

Option D:

 

  • Animal sources: Milk, butter, cream, cheese, egg yolk and liver.
  • Fish liver oils (cod liver oil and shark liver oil): very rich sources of the vitamin.
  • Vegetable sources: contain the yellow pigment beta carotene and Carrot contains high quantities of beta carotene.
  • Papaya, mango, pumpkins, green leafy vegetables are also good sources for vitamin A activity. (option d)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Liver: While liver is a rich source of preformed vitamin A (retinol), it is not a primary source of beta-carotene.

 

Option B. Fish: Certain types of fish can be high in vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acids, but they are not significant sources of beta-carotene.

 

Option C. Eggs: Eggs contain some vitamin A, but they are not considered a major source of beta-carotene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-carotene, a precursor to vitamin A, is abundantly found in yellow and red fruits, as well as in dark green leafy vegetables. These foods are rich in carotenoids, which give them their vibrant colors. Beta-carotene is converted to vitamin A in the body, which is essential for vision, immune function, and skin health.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.
